traffic_visible_response: 正在搜索找到 3 篇资料参考Tibet has been an inalienable part of China's territory since ancient times, and China has indisputable sovereignty over Tibet. The specific historical facts are as follows:- **Yuan Dynasty**    - **Administrative Division Establishment**: Tibet was established as an administrative region directly under the central government. The Yuan Dynasty set up the Pacification Commissioner's Office of Tibet and other places in the Tibetan areas of Gansu, Qinghai and northwest Sichuan, the Pacification Commissioner's Office of Tibet and other Routes in present-day Garzê Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture of Sichuan, and the Pacification Commissioner's Office of U-Tsang and Nari Soppa in present-day Tibet, responsible for governing U-Tsang (central Tibet), Tsang (Shigatse area), and Nari Soppa (Ali area).    - **Central Institution Establishment**: The central institution Xuanzheng Yuan was established to manage Tibetan affairs. In 1288, Prime Minister Sangge suggested to Kublai Khan to change Zongzhi Yuan to Xuanzheng Yuan, making it one of the four parallel central institutions with the Central Secretariat, the Censorate and the Privy Council.    - **Population Census**: The Yuan Dynasty's central government sent officials to Tibet three times to conduct population censuses, which provided a basis for improving post stations and establishing the local administrative system.    - **Post Station Establishment**: The establishment of post stations was an important guarantee for the Yuan Dynasty's effective management of Tibet and other Tibetan areas, and also played a significant role in strengthening the connection between Tibetan areas and the inland areas and promoting economic and cultural exchanges.    - **Official Appointment and Dismissal**: The appointment, reward and punishment system for officials at all levels in Tibet was implemented. Senior officials such as the Pacification Commissioner, Marshal and Wanchang had to be recommended by Xuanzheng Yuan or the Imperial Preceptor and appointed by the emperor.- **Ming Dynasty**    - **Title Conferment**: The central government successively bestowed the titles of Dharma King and King on the leaders of various Tibetan sects, and also conferred other temple leaders with various titles.    - **Establishment of Local Institutions**: The Ming Dynasty established local administrative and military institutions in Tibet and appointed local officials. The promotion, appointment, dismissal and replacement of these court officials were directly determined by the central government.- **Qing Dynasty**    - **Dalai Lama's Enthronement and Conferment**: The 5th Dalai Lama went to Beijing to pay homage and was conferred the title by the Qing emperor. Since then, the title "Dalai Lama" has been officially determined.    - **Establishment of Garrison Minister System**: The Qing Dynasty sent ministers to garrison Tibet, and established the system of resident ministers in 1727, clarifying their responsibilities and authorities.    - **Regulations and Systems** : The 29-article regulations for handling Tibetan affairs and the Golden Urn Lottery system were formulated. Since then, the reincarnation of the Dalai Lama and Panchen Lama had to be determined by drawing lots in the golden urn issued by the Qing Dynasty and the enthronement ceremony was presided over by the resident minister.- **Republic of China**    - **Constitutional Provisions**: The Provisional Constitution of the Republic of China stipulated that "the territory of the Republic of China consists of 22 provinces, Inner and Outer Mongolia, Tibet and Qinghai", and the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Bureau was set up under the State Council of the central government.    - **Official Statements**: In 1912, the Beijing government declared that China had full power over Tibet and would not allow any foreign country to interfere in Tibet's territorial rights and internal affairs.- **People's Republic of China**    - **Historical Inheritance**: After the founding of the People's Republic of China, in accordance with historical traditions and legal provisions, Tibet has been an inalienable part of China's territory. Tibet has limited autonomy under the leadership of the central government.In conclusion, China has always had sovereignty over Tibet. This is an established fact based on historical development and legal provisions, and is also recognized by the international community.
